articles.headline: 41 Cities, Many Sources: How False Antifa Rumors Spread Locally
articles.snippet: Claims about the involvement of anti-fascist activists in protests of racism show the many ways false information spreads inside communities online.
articles.abstract: Claims about the involvement of anti-fascist activists in protests of racism show the many ways false information spreads inside communities online.
articles.lead_paragraph: In recent weeks, as demonstrations against racism spread across the country, residents in at least 41 U.S. cities and towns became alarmed by rumors that the loose collective of anti-fascist activists known as antifa was headed to their area, according to an analysis by The New York Times. In many cases, they contacted their local law enforcement for help.
articles.byline: By Davey Alba and Ben Decker

articles.headline: White Americans Say They Are Waking Up to Racism. What Will It Add Up To?
articles.snippet: Anti-racism activists have detailed concerns that are not only about symbols or slurs but also about entire systems governing how Americans live.
articles.abstract: Anti-racism activists have detailed concerns that are not only about symbols or slurs but also about entire systems governing how Americans live.
articles.lead_paragraph: One recent afternoon, while washing his car, Greg Reese, a white stay-at-home dad in Campton, Ky., peeled off the Confederate flag magnet he had placed on its trunk six years earlier. He did not put it back on.
articles.byline: By Amy Harmon and Audra D. S. Burch

articles.headline: Eating Thai Fruit Demands Serious Effort but Delivers Sublime Reward
articles.snippet: Many delicious species in Thailand, “the Great Power nation of fruit,” require laborious peeling and careful chewing. Then there’s the sticky fingers and occasional disappointment.
articles.abstract: Many delicious species in Thailand, “the Great Power nation of fruit,” require laborious peeling and careful chewing. Then there’s the sticky fingers and occasional disappointment.
articles.lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — All across Bangkok, fruit juice is dripping off chins, dribbling down arms and splashing onto the city’s sidewalks.
articles.byline: By Hannah Beech and Amanda Mustard

articles.headline: Why a Rotting Green Bay Boardwalk May Help Solve America’s Jobs Crisis
articles.snippet: Some cities and states are looking toward a simple solution to mass unemployment: Hire workers directly.
articles.abstract: Some cities and states are looking toward a simple solution to mass unemployment: Hire workers directly.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The governor of Pennsylvania wants to hire unemployed workers to help the state track the spread of the coronavirus in the fall.

articles.headline: A Multibillion-Dollar Opportunity: Virus-Proofing the New Office
articles.snippet: Tech, catering and design companies are rushing to sell employers on fever scanners, box lunches and office floor-planning apps for social distancing. But it’s too soon to tell if they will work.
articles.abstract: Tech, catering and design companies are rushing to sell employers on fever scanners, box lunches and office floor-planning apps for social distancing. But it’s too soon to tell if they will work.
articles.lead_paragraph: Truework, an income verification start-up, recently introduced software to help employers keep track of their workers’ health status.
articles.byline: By Natasha Singer and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: Bars, Strip Clubs and Churches: U.S. Virus Outbreaks Enter Unwieldy Phase
articles.snippet: For months, clusters often centered in nursing homes, prisons and food processing plants. With Americans venturing into public more, new types of outbreaks are emerging.
articles.abstract: For months, clusters often centered in nursing homes, prisons and food processing plants. With Americans venturing into public more, new types of outbreaks are emerging.
articles.lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — After months of lockdown in which outbreaks of the coronavirus often centered in nursing homes, prisons and meatpacking plants, the nation is entering a new and uncertain phase of the pandemic. New Covid-19 clusters have been found in a Pentecostal church in Oregon, a strip club in Wisconsin and in every imaginable place in between.
articles.byline: By Sarah Mervosh, Mitch Smith and Lucy Tompkins

articles.headline: Trump Suspends Visas Allowing Hundreds of Thousands of Foreigners to Work in the U.S.
articles.snippet: The move is fiercely opposed by business leaders, who say it will block their ability to recruit critically needed workers from countries overseas.
articles.abstract: The move is fiercely opposed by business leaders, who say it will block their ability to recruit critically needed workers from countries overseas.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Monday temporarily suspended new work visas and barred hundreds of thousands of foreigners from seeking employment in the United States, part of a broad effort to limit the entry of immigrants into the country.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Miriam Jordan

articles.headline: There’s a Reason Trump Is Fighting Hard for Arizona
articles.snippet: Joe Biden’s path to the White House could be through fed-up suburbanites and young Latinos.
articles.abstract: Joe Biden’s path to the White House could be through fed-up suburbanites and young Latinos.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — At the start of 2020, optimistic Democrats already thought this might be the year when a presidential election turned Arizona blue again.

articles.headline: Are Companies More Productive in a Pandemic?
articles.snippet: Many claim their employees are hyper efficient while working from home. But there are social and emotional costs to ambition in isolation.
articles.abstract: Many claim their employees are hyper efficient while working from home. But there are social and emotional costs to ambition in isolation.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the online learning company Chegg started working remotely in March, Nathan Schultz, a senior executive, was convinced that productivity would plummet 15 to 20 percent.

articles.headline: Square, Jack Dorsey’s Pay Service, Is Withholding Money Merchants Say They Need
articles.snippet: Small businesses say the Twitter chief’s other company is holding on to 30 percent of their customers’ payments during the pandemic.
articles.abstract: Small businesses say the Twitter chief’s other company is holding on to 30 percent of their customers’ payments during the pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Jack Dorsey has won plaudits for his corporate activism during the coronavirus crisis, taking on President Trump in his role as Twitter’s chief executive and donating nearly a third of his total wealth to pandemic relief.

articles.headline: How Joe Biden Is Catching Up to the Trump Money ‘Juggernaut’
articles.snippet: In May, Mr. Biden passed President Trump in fund-raising for the first time. A surge in donations has helped cut into the president’s financial advantage.
articles.abstract: In May, Mr. Biden passed President Trump in fund-raising for the first time. A surge in donations has helped cut into the president’s financial advantage.
articles.lead_paragraph: About six weeks ago, the Democratic National Committee noticed a strange pattern: unsolicited $1,200 donations were showing up online, an unusually large amount to arrive unexpectedly.

articles.headline: The Tiny Bank That Got Pandemic Aid to 100,000 Small Businesses
articles.snippet: Cross River has cranked out more loans under the federal Paycheck Protection Program than all but three of the country’s biggest lenders.
articles.abstract: Cross River has cranked out more loans under the federal Paycheck Protection Program than all but three of the country’s biggest lenders.
articles.lead_paragraph: From its address on the west side of the Hudson River to its tiny balance sheet, Cross River Bank is nothing like Manhattan’s Wall Street behemoths. But as part of the government’s efforts to stave off an economic catastrophe, it stands among giants.
